definition[0]: to show that something is definitely true, especially by providing more proof
example[0]: New evidence has confirmed the first witness’s story.
example[1]: To confirm my diagnosis I need to do some tests.
example[2]: Research has confirmed that the risk is higher for women.
example[3]: The new results confirm what most of us knew already.
explanation[0]: In more formal English, you say it is confirmed that something is true
example[4]: It was confirmed that the bone was broken
definition[1]: to say that something is definitely true
example[5]: The president refused to confirm the rumor.
example[6]: Managers have so far refused to confirm or deny reports that up to 200 jobs are to go.
example[7]: Walsh confirmed that the money had been paid.
example[8]: My brother will confirm what I have told you.
definition[2]: to tell someone that a possible arrangement, date, or situation is now definite or official
example[9]: Could you confirm the dates we discussed?
example[10]: Smith was confirmed as the club’s new manager yesterday.
example[11]: I am writing to confirm a booking for a single room for the night of 6 June.
definition[3]: to make you believe that your idea or feeling is right
example[12]: This just confirms my worst fears.
example[13]: The expression on his face confirmed me in my suspicions.
note[4]: confirm you in your belief/opinion/view etc (that)
definition[4]: if a piece of new information confirms  an idea or belief that people already have, it shows that it is definitely true
example[14]: Police have found new evidence that confirms his story.
example[15]: The discovery seems to confirm that people lived here over 10,000 years ago.
definition[5]: to show that something is definitely true by providing facts
example[16]: DNA tests proved that he was the father of the child.
example[17]: I think we’ve proved that we are a good team.
definition[6]: to provide additional information to help prove that a statement, belief, or explanation is correct
example[18]: When you write a history essay, you should back up all your points with facts.
example[19]: Wright was accused of pretending to be injured, and this was backed up by video evidence.
definition[7]: to help to prove that a belief, idea etc is probably true
example[20]: Do you have any evidence to support these claims?
example[21]: The notion that women are worse drivers than men is simply not supported by the facts.
definition[8]: if facts or information bear out a claim or opinion, they suggest that something is likely to be true
example[22]: Most of the available evidence bears out the view that students learn better in small classes.
example[23]: Marriage is not always easy; a fact that is clearly borne out in divorce statistics.
definition[9]: to provide additional information which supports or agrees with something – used in scientific and legal contexts
example[24]: Levine claims that a third car was involved in the accident and witnesses have corroborated this.
example[25]: Professor Carling’s findings have been corroborated by more recent research.
definition[10]: to provide additional information that helps to prove that a statement is correct, especially if the statement is difficult to believe
example[26]: A police investigation failed to substantiate the claim that he had been sexually abused.
definition[11]: to prove that information or results are correct by using scientific tests or very careful checking – used in scientific or technical contexts
example[27]: All the information used in this report has been validated by an independent panel of experts.
definition[12]: to say or show that something is definitely true
example[28]: The company said the report confirmed what its own directors and accountants had already established.
definition[13]: to tell someone that a possible arrangement, date, or time is now definite
example[29]: I am writing to confirm our order for a 500mm print.
example[30]: If a confirmed booking is cancelled a 50% fee will be charged.
